summary: What's News: World-Wide for October 1, 2010.

summary: What's News: Business & Finance for October 1, 2010.

headline: Calif. Budget Deal Headed for Vote
summary: California's statehouse leaders said they reached an agreement on a budget that would close a $19.1 billion shortfall for the fiscal year ending next June.

headline: The Weathervane on the Auction Block
summary: Made from molds to adorn American barns and churches from the Colonial era to the Gilded Age, copper weathervane prices are easy to track, thanks to their ubiquity in the market and their archetypal designs. Here are a handful of rare, historic examples.

headline: Photo-Op: The Hat Madder
summary: Isabella Blow inspired fashion as well as followed it.

headline: The Last Speakers
summary: For his new book, "The Last Speakers: The Quest to Save the World's Most Endangered Languages" (National Geographic Books, 2010), K. David Harrison and his team traveled around the world to interview the few remaining speakers of dying languages, from Siberia to Bolivia.

headline: Relaxed Fine Dining
summary: SoHo's Shorty's .32, which features familiar brunch dishes, offers fine dining in a small, causal setting.

headline: Hourglass-Shaped Fashions for the Everyday
summary: Fall styles showcased by Louis Vuitton, Prada and Miu Miu, among others, celebrate a well-endowed figure. Today's iteration of the curvy look is balanced and ladylike and elegance is key. Here's a guide to how to get the look.

headline: Spill-Fund Overseer Says 'Scams' Flourish
summary: The lawyer overseeing the $20 billion oil-spill claims fund set up after the Deepwater Horizon disaster has referred a claim to the Justice Department for possible prosecution for fraud, and said "scams" were bogging down his efforts.

headline: Greater New York Watch
summary: A roundup of area news

headline: J&J Warns of Sales-Force Layoffs
summary: Johnson & Johnson has warned sales representatives to be prepared for layoffs if generic versions of its blockbuster drug for attention-deficit disorder hit the market.

headline: Repsol Cashes In on China's Oil Chase
summary: The Sinopec deal gives Repsol the funds to develop its 1.2 billion barrels of Brazilian oil reserves, a relief for the Spanish oil group's shareholders.

headline: ISM Report Keeps Leash on Dow
summary: The Dow industrials closed up 41.63 points, or 0.4%, at 10829.68. But blue chips fell 0.3% for the week, snapping a four-week winning streak.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Suspect in Swiss Data Theft Found Dead
summary: A man suspected of stealing Swiss bank account information and selling it in Germany was found dead in his Swiss prison cell after what police said appeared to be suicide.

headline: Senator Questions McDonald's Health Plans
summary: A top Senate Democrat is asking a health insurer that provides plans for McDonald's restaurant workers to disclose details of the plans to the Senate.

headline: ChinaCache Jumps in Debut
summary: Internet-services provider ChinaCache's stock nearly doubled in the best IPO debut in the U.S. in three years, overshadowing KEYW Holding and China Ming Yang on their first day of trading.

headline: Fed Talk Dents Dollar
summary: The dollar fell Friday against all major rivals, with the focus on potential Federal Reserve stimulus diverting attention from encouraging U.S. economic data.

headline: Flash Answer
summary: None

headline: TNK-BP Board OKs BP Offer
summary: TNK-BP, BP's Russian joint venture, has decided to make BP a formal offer for its assets in Vietnam and Venezuela, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Microsoft Fills Executive Gaps
summary: Microsoft reshuffled its executive ranks, naming three new presidents to lead its Office, mobile and videogame businesses as the company faces big challenges for each of the groups.

headline: Treasurys Mixed After Data
summary: Treasurys maturing in seven years or less rebounded while long-dated maturities recouped most of their earlier losses after a key gauge of the U.S. manufacturing sector fell.

headline: Gold Jumps to Another Record
summary: Gold returned to a record high with a vengeance, settling above $1,316 an ounce as investors sought bullion as an alternative to currencies.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 1
summary: In Friday's pictures, rain slams the Northeast, a man is publicly whipped in Indonesia, India prepares to celebrate Gandhi and more.

headline: Learn to Be a Matador
summary: At the Dennis C. Borba Bullfighting School in Escalon, Calif., students study under a master of classical bullfighting, learning the moves and postures of the sport.

headline: Aboard Hugh Hefner's Custom Jet, the Big Bunny
summary: After travelling to London in 1966, Hugh Hefner decided to design his own custom plane. "I saw the future when I was in London: The sexual revolution was going on and the miniskirt had just arrived. I decided then and there to get the jet," he said.

headline: Riding Out From Fort Drum
summary: Members of the U.S. Army's Sixth Squadron, Sixth Cavalry Regiment out of Ford Drum, N.Y., participated this week in a "spur ride," a voluntary test of their military training and physical fitness.

headline: Mining for Gold in Old Tax Returns
summary: Small-business owners looking for tax relief would be wise to review the past years' filings. There may be opportunities for refunds and reminders for deductions.

headline: BP's Dudley Again Asked to Face Lawmakers
summary: CEO Robert Dudley is under pressure to appear before lawmakers now that he has officially assumed the top job at BP.

headline: Europe Slips; India, Japan Gain
summary: European stocks started the month on a mildly negative note as investors absorbed a wave of U.S. economic data, while Indian shares rose to their highest in nearly 33 months.

headline: UniCredit's Boardroom Fiasco
summary: UniCredit's boardroom bust-up has been a fiasco, raising questions over the judgment of Chairman Dieter Rampl and the long-term leadership and strategy of the bank.

headline: Repsol Sells Brazil Oil Stake to Sinopec
summary: Repsol agreed to sell 40% of its Brazilian unit to China's Sinopec for $7.1 billion, securing key funding to explore coveted oil fields in South America's largest country.

headline: Lennar Acquires Distressed Real-Estate Assets
summary: The home builder's purchase of $740 million in loans and real estate came from three unnamed financial institutions.

headline: European Stocks Start Month in the Red
summary: European stocks started the month on a mildly negative note as investors absorbed a wave of U.S. economic data, although shares in London eked out a gain.

headline: Bin Laden Statements Allowed at Trial
summary: Prosecutors will be able to introduce statements by Osama bin Laden at the trial of a Tanzanian man accused in a plot to blow up two U.S. embassies in Africa in 1998, a judge ruled.

headline: EarthLink Buys Fiber-Network Operator
summary: EarthLink agreed to acquire fiber-optic network operator ITC DeltaCom for $191 million plus debt, as the Internet provider moves toward a heavier focus on businesses.

headline: The Anglo Irish Sub Debt Puzzle
summary: A fight may be about to break out over Anglo Irish Bank. The Irish government is determined to get subordinated-debt holders to share the pain.

headline: NATO Committed to Georgia Inclusion
summary: NATO remains committed to admitting Georgia to its ranks, the head of the alliance said, as the pro-Western former Soviet country suffered its greatest losses yet in Afghanistan.

headline: New Delhi Guide
summary: Top places to see, shop and eat at around five of the main Commonwealth Games venues.

headline: IKEA Lifts Lid on Earnings
summary: Swedish furniture giant IKEA released full-year earnings figures for the first time in its history, part of efforts to shake off its secretive image.

headline: India Looks to Its Stars
summary: The Commonwealth Games have been couched as a way for India to showcase its strengths to the world. Now the pressure is on the home-country athletes like Saina Nehwal.

headline: Brenntag Raises $911.1 Million
summary: Private-equity investors in German chemical distributor Brenntag sold 11 million shares, raising $911.1 million six months after an initial public offering.

headline: Spain, Ireland Woes Hit Markets
summary: European stock markets edged lower as investors digested details of the Irish banking bailout and Moody's downgrade of Spain.

headline: Federal Agency Flexible On McDonald's Plan
summary: The Obama administration said its top health official will "exercise her discretion" in enforcing a new health-law requirement, a move that could prevent McDonald's and other employers from disrupting their health-care policies.

headline: BMW to Recall 345,000 Cars
summary: German car maker BMW said it will recall 345,000 cars world-wide due to potential problems with the power braking system, including 5,800 Rolls-Royce Phantoms.

headline: Cameron to Set Up Business Council
summary: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron announced he will convene a Business Advisory Council to offer advice and present the concerns of the business community.

headline: Russia and U.S. Reach WTO Agreement
summary: The U.S. and Russia have settled all of their differences regarding Moscow's bid to join the World Trade Organization, Finance Minister Alexei Kudrin said.

headline: Credit Unions Receive TARP Bailout Funds
summary: The U.S. Treasury in recent weeks provided 48 credit unions with $69.91 million through a program aimed at boosting small-business lending in underserved communities.

headline: Analysts: Asia's Currencies to Pull Back
summary: Most Asian currencies will pull back this quarter as central banks step up their foreign-exchange intervention, helping the dollar pause in its steep slide, analysts predict.

headline: How to Bet Like John Paulson
summary: The hedge fund tycoon just made three big financial calls you need to know about, writes Brett Arends.

headline: Five Cities for the Career-Minded Student
summary: SmartMoney.com looks at the top five small metropolitan areas for college students who want to stick around for work after graduation.

headline: An Insider's Guide to the Treasures of Milan
summary: Milan is a city where business and creativity go hand in hand—in fashion, architecture and every type of "design." Many of its cultural gems are hidden; you have to get to know the Italian city to find them. Here are some great spots to visit, recommended by those in the know.

headline: Week in Review
summary: View this week's top stories at OpinionJournal.com.

headline: GM Accelerates Full-Size SUVs
summary: General Motors is accelerating its plan for a new line of full-size SUVs, with launch now slated for 2014.

headline: The Subaru WRX STI Limited Sedan
summary: The 2011 Subaru WRX STI is an extra souped-up version of the carmaker's Impreza. The new Limited Sedan model brings back the signature rear wing. Here's closer a look.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Yields on Japanese government bonds generally rose, as a stronger stock market chipped away at demand for safe-haven assets.

headline: Perfect Financial Storm for Reinsurers
summary: Reinsurers are facing an industry challenge of regulatory uncertainty and surplus capital. Without a major catastrophe, sector valuations look set to remain at multiyear lows.

headline: India Regulator Bars Some Investors
summary: India's capital-markets regulator has barred some foreign institutional investors from taking fresh positions in the local cash and derivatives markets for failing to comply with disclosure rules.

headline: At the Games Village
summary: Some snapshots of daily life at the Commonwealth Games Village in New Delhi.

headline: Titans Meet for Another Footy Final
summary: The Collingwood Magpies and St. Kilda Saints meet again in Melbourne for a replay to decide the Australian Football League title after last Saturday's Grand Final match ended in a tie.

headline: Tate Exhibit Makes Case for Gauguin
summary: Gauguin's paintings aren't so much to today's taste, but the Tate Modern's "Gauguin: Maker of Myth" tries to make a different case for the man who, for generations, has represented the essence of the bohemian artist.

headline: BP Pledges Assets as Gulf Spill Collateral
summary: BP said it has pledged several U.S. Gulf of Mexico assets as collateral for the $20 billion Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill Trust, set up to pay claims from the disaster.

headline: Photos: Anjaana Anjaani
summary: Bollywood big release this week stars Ranbir Kapoor and Priyanka Chopra. Some snapshots.

headline: Maruti, Mahindra, Hyundai Post Record Sales
summary: Most auto makers in India continued to post record vehicle sales in September as dealers bought more cars and motorcycles in anticipation of higher demand in the upcoming festive season.

headline: India Court Stays Vedanta Unit's Plant Closure
summary: Vedanta Resources has received a temporary relief in India as its unit, Sterlite Industries (India, said the country's top court has stayed a lower court order to close its sole copper smelter.

headline: German Retail Sales Drop
summary: In a surprise, retail sales in Germany fell in August, casting doubt on a strong recovery of the country's weak private consumption.

headline: Japan Auto Sales Down
summary: The end of major subsidies midway through the month dragged down Japan's domestic auto sales for the first time in 14 months.

headline: Japan Counts on the Other Asian Market
summary: Amid all the talk of the BRIC group of nations, one of the fastest growing markets in the world doesn't get as much attention. That's Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand—the MITs.

headline: South Africa's Manufacturing Sector Falters
summary: The health of South Africa's manufacturing sector, which led the continent's biggest economy out of recession last year, continued to falter in September.

headline: Euro-Zone Manufacturing Slows
summary: The growth of manufacturing activity in the 16 countries that share the euro slowed in September, while activity declined in Ireland, Spain and Greece.

headline: Euro-Zone Unemployment Holds Steady
summary: The euro zone's unemployment rate was unchanged at 10.1% in August, although the number of people without work fell by 20,000 to 15.9 million.

headline: Kan Renews Yen Intervention Threat
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan, in his speech opening the first parliament session after a political fight that threatened his career, reiterated his government's recent statements on the economy.

headline: Air India Says on Track to Join Star Alliance
summary: Air India said it is on track to join Star Alliance, the world's biggest network of airlines, by the first quarter of 2011.

headline: Asian Stocks Mostly Higher
summary: Asian stock markets were up Friday, as beaten down stocks in Tokyo attracted buyers. The Nikkei climbed 0.4%.

headline: Quoddy
summary: Quoddys take a bit of getting used to aesthetically but their light crepe soles, full-grained sheepskin liners and hand-sewn uppers, which made them so handy for deer hunting in Maine, also mark them out on the street as boots with integrity and longevity.

headline: Asian Economic Data Show Solid Footing
summary: An expansion of manufacturing in China and India, and strong Korean exports in September suggest Asia's economies will remain on a solid footing in coming months, despite a pickup in food inflation.

headline: Wen Says China Will Support Greece
summary: Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao will deliver a clear "vote of confidence" in the prospects for Greece's economy when he visits the nation this weekend.

headline: Alfa Laval Raises Munters Bid
summary: Swedish engineer Alfa Laval raised its cash offer for Munters to $823.6 million after its original offer was trumped by private-equity fund Cidron Intressenter.

headline: UniCredit Taps Ghizzoni as CEO
summary: The board of Italian bank UniCredit named Federico Ghizzoni as its new chief executive officer and said that its governance committee will propose structural changes in coming weeks.

headline: The Ayodhya Verdict Announcement
summary: The Court announced its verdict on the disputed religious site in Ayodhya Thursday. Some snapshots of anxious moments around India as the verdict was announced.

headline: Japan Consumer Prices Fall 1%
summary: Japan's core consumer price index fell 1% from a year earlier in August, another sign that the country's economy remains mired in deflation.

headline: Deal Making Increases in Europe
summary: In another sign that the outlook for deals is improving, the dollar volume of takeovers in Europe rose 19% in the third quarter from a year earlier to $205.5 billion, according to research firm Dealogic.

headline: Daewoo Names New CEO
summary: Daewoo International's board named the former chief financial officer of its new owner, steelmaker Posco, as its chief executive and vice chairman, with plans to deepen ties between the two companies.

headline: China's Manufacturing Growing
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded in September, an official gauge showed, adding evidence that Chinese growth remains robust.

headline: IPOs Pick Up the Pace
summary: New-stock issuance remains well off the pace of a few years ago, but activity so far this year has already surpassed that seen in the entirety of 2009. See also: Agricultural Bank of China and its $22 billion debut.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: New Delhi gearing up for the Commonwealth Games, athletes practice for the upcoming Commonwealth Games, a view of the Taj Mahal and more.

headline: Police Strike in Ecuador
summary: The government declared a state of siege Thursday after rebellious police angered by a law that cuts their benefits plunged this small South American nation into chaos, roughing up the president, shutting down airports and blocking highways in a nationwide strike.

headline: AIG Policyholders Safe, Say States
summary: State regulators who oversee some of the biggest AIG insurance units say the company's plan for repaying U.S. taxpayers isn't expected to touch any of the money protecting policyholders.

headline: Spain Releases Terrorism Suspect
summary: A U.S. citizen of Algerian origin arrested in Spain on allegations that he funneled funds to an al Qaeda cell was released due to lack of evidence, though the investigation remains open.

headline: Bogeyman Boehner
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  Democrats are planning to portray John Boehner as a Beltway insider beholden to lobbyists for corporate interests.

headline: General Growth Scion Denied Seat
summary: In a final slap to the family that founded mall giant General Growth Properties, the overseers of the bankrupt company have decided against giving the Bucksbaums any representation on the company's boards or executive offices.

headline: Closer to the Puritans  Than Was Intended
summary: In his letter of Sept. 27 Imran Javaid favorably compares Muslim immigrants to the Puritans. The Puritans came seeking religious freedom, then denied that freedom to anyone who did not share their beliefs.

headline: Fisher-Price Agrees to Recalls
summary: Federal product safety regulators have recalled about 10 million Fisher Price products, including seven million tricycles that could cause genital bleeding if a child strikes, sits or falls on a protruding plastic ignition key.

headline: Strassel: Thank Obama for the GOP Revival
summary: Republican gains on the state level could change the political map for years to come.

headline: Creating a Seasonal Menu
summary: With the fresh arrival of oysters, game and root vegetables to the top kitchens in Europe, Bruce Palling discovers how chefs go about creating a seasonal menu.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: China's New Diplomacy
summary: Beijing drives its neighbors into the arms of the U.S.

headline: Whirlpool Unit Fined Along With Panasonic
summary: Panasonic and Whirlpool will plead guilty to conspiring to fix prices on refrigerant compressors and pay $140.9 million in criminal fines.

headline: Crouching Yahoo, Hidden Dragon
summary: Liberty Media Chairman John Malone could be just the person Yahoo needs to figure out how to tax-effectively unlock the value of its Asian investments.

headline: Chances for Hope
summary: With strong acting and the right tone, Fox's new sitcom—about a blue-collar family of misfits with a newborn baby suddenly dropped in their midst—avoids the usual sentimental clichés.

headline: Boy, 8, Dies in Brooklyn Fire
summary: Fire officials were investigating Thursday the cause of a fire that broke out at a Brooklyn home late Wednesday, killing an 8-year-old boy and injuring five of his siblings.

headline: Lorenz Maroldt: The Lives of Nazis, the Stasi and Others
summary: Twenty years after German reunification, facing the past remains a necessary challenge.

headline: Cops Denied Federal Funds
summary: New York City will receive no money from a federal program to help cities hire more police officers, marking a second year in a row the Obama administration has denied such funds to the city's force.

headline: BP Expects Dividend Next Year
summary: BP chief Robert Dudley expressed confidence that the company can resume paying its dividend next year and that it has set aside enough money for liabilities from the Gulf oil spill.

headline: Accounts Raided in Global Bank Hack
summary: More than 100 people have been charged in the U.S. and the U.K. as part of a global cybercrime ring that allegedly used malicious computer viruses to steal bank-account information and loot millions from unsuspecting victims.

headline: Cano Gets In the Endorsement Game
summary: As he nears the end of a breakout year, second baseman Robinson Cano is appearing in a series of Nike commercials that are expected to air during the postseason.

headline: High-End Real Estate Holdouts
summary: More than four years after the housing market peaked, many wealthy homeowners are slashing prices. Then there are the holdouts: wealthy sellers who are holding the line on today's deal-making mentality.

headline: This Marriage Goes the Distance
summary: Like many of the world's elite runners, Gebre Gebremariam and Werknesh Kidane will be traveling to New York in November to compete in the ING New York City Marathon. But the two Ethiopians share an unusual connection: They are also married.

headline: Christie Calls for Lower State Taxes
summary: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie said he wants to lower the state income tax rate to 6% from the current 9% for top earners by the end of his four-year term.

headline: Port Authority Chairman Nominated
summary: Christie nominated as chairman of the Port Authority David Samson, a prominent attorney who for years had as a client World Trade Center developer Larry Silverstein.

headline: A Guide to This Week's Arts and Entertainment
summary: A look at "Secretariat," Hardly Strictly Bluegrass and "Driving Miss Daisy." Plus, Betsy Ross at Winterthur, "Sins of My Father" on HBO.

headline: Ruth R. Wisse: At Harvard, Groupthink About Islam
summary: A liberal editor stands accused of anti-Muslim bigotry.

headline: Austerity Plan Spurs Bond Rush
summary: A measure on the Colorado ballot for November would ban all borrowing by the state and curb it at the municipal level, making Colorado the only U.S. state whose agencies are unable to issue debt.

headline: Global Stocks Gain as Growth Emerges
summary: After a harrowing second quarter, investors around the world shook off most of their jitters and embraced a rosier, if not entirely clear, global economic picture.

headline: High design in Hong Kong
summary: A British designer revamps a luxury penthouse: grand and sophisticated, with an edgy look.

headline: Currencies Swing on Weak Outlooks
summary: In the last quarter, foreign-exchange traders wrestled with assessing which struggling economy was struggling most.

headline: A World Series Game Gets Earlier Start
summary: Game 3 of the World Series is moved up to 6:57 p.m. ET, Bill Parcells hints that he's not done, and the Couch prepares for Ryder Cup, Alabama-Florida and Eagles-Redskins.

headline: New Formula Leads to Grade Drop for Schools
summary: The Department of Education released the letter graes for 1,140 elementary school-level schools, with nearly 65% seeing a drop. The changes mostly reflect changes in the formula used to grade schools.

headline: Despite Contador, NY Cyclists Roll On
summary: With Mr. Contador's crisis, a sport that has already overdosed on the surreal adds another bizarro chapter to its history.

headline: The Repeal Pledge
summary: Holding politicians to their promise to replace ObamaCare.

headline: Veteran Aide to Replace Emanuel
summary: Rahm Emanuel will step down as White House chief of staff Friday to explore a run for mayor of Chicago, officials said. His successor, at least temporarily, is expected to be Pete Rouse.

headline: Plane Fires Prompt Battery Safeguards
summary: U.S. regulators are expected to crack down on air-cargo shipments of computers and other electronics that contain lithium ion batteries, prompted by the recent fiery crash of a UPS cargo jet filled with electronic goods.

headline: Housing Holdouts
summary: Tour the multi-million dollar homes of some sellers who are refusing to cut asking prices.

headline: Connecticut Estate Asks $42.5 Million
summary: A waterfront Connecticut estate asks $42.5 million, Lilly Pulitzer lists her Palm Beach, Fla., home for $11.5 million and Adam Carolla sells a Los Angeles home for $1.18 million.

headline: Landlords Squeeze Poor for Extra Rent
summary: Unscrupulous landlords are pressuring poverty-stricken participants in a city-subsidized housing program to pay additional rent beyond the lease terms -- and the mayor is turning a blind eye.

headline: N. Korea Heir Appears, at Last
summary: North Korea's biggest newspaper published a front-page photo of Kim Jong Eun, the son and heir apparent of dictator Kim Jong Il.

headline: Whitman Accuser Stokes Dispute
summary: A Mexican immigrant showed a letter she said bolstered her claim that California gubernatorial candidate Meg Whitman employed her despite knowing her illegal status.

headline: Berlin's Real-Estate Transformation
summary: Twenty years after the reunification of Germany, and billions spent on rebuilding, the East has been tamed and living in Berlin is being transformed.

headline: Hungary's Fidesz Set for Win
summary: Riding a surge in popularity after refusing to back down to the International Monetary Fund, Hungary's governing Fidesz party is set to win a landslide victory in local elections Sunday.

headline: How to Start a Trade War
summary: When it comes to the debate over China's currency, the voices of moderation are getting edged out.

headline: U.K. Bank Panel Looks Doomed to Fail
summary: What are the chances the U.K.'s Independent Commission on Banking will prove genuinely radical and successfully bring about the break-up of U.K. banks, whether on financial stability or competition grounds? Surely, close to zero.

headline: Cultural Calendar
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to what's on around Europe.

headline: The Best of the New York Film Festival
summary: One week down, one to go at the New York Film Festival, but there's still a lot see. Here are some recommendations from our staff.

headline: Bond Market Rallies, but Risks Lurk
summary: As investors continued to pour spare cash into bond funds and snub stock funds, troubles burbling beneath surface may have been missed.

headline: Board at Center of Pension Storm
summary: The board that sets accounting rules for municipal governments is coming under fire for its makeup and a proposal on how pension calculations are made.

headline: J&J Told It Moved Too Late
summary: Johnson & Johnson's over-the-counter drug unit repeatedly failed to investigate and fix problems with its products, federal regulators told a congressional panel.

headline: Chicken With Crunch
summary: The idea behind Hill Country Chicken, a new restaurant that's all about fried chicken and pies, is to take 'what Grandmother put on the table and make it for 1,000 people.'

headline: Big Personality Out, Smaller Agenda In
summary: Rahm Emanuel has been one of those rare White House chiefs of staff who played the inside policy game and the outside political game with equal vigor.

headline: Bosnian Serb Leader Takes Tough Line
summary: Bosnian Serb leader Milorad Dodik called Bosnia and Herzegovina's creation as "a mistake" and ruled out a coalition with a moderate Bosnian Muslim party.

headline: Pushcarts Gone, Hester Street Area Seeks New Life
summary: Once home to the city's largest and oldest pushcart market, the newly trendy pocket around Hester and Essex streets on the Lower East Side is experiencing a burst of activity on several fronts.

headline: South Carolina Isn't Going Greene
summary: The troubled candidacy of Senate hopeful Alvin Greene in South Carolina has virtually assured a victory for his GOP opponent, Sen. Jim DeMint.

headline: Calif. Extends Foster-Care Help
summary: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a bill extending foster-care support to young adults between the ages of 18 and 21, a move cited as a bellwether by child-welfare advocates.
